By the 17th century, origami was part of: When did origami become part of Japanese society? History of origami in Japan 17th century

In the Edo period (1603-1868) origami became more widespread in Japanese society due to the reduced price of washi paper. This gave rise to the cultural practice of formal gift wrappers (noshi) along with envelopes/paper purses (tato), and letter folds for a larger population of society.
When did origami become part of Japanese society? History of origami in Japan 17th century

With increased production methods in the 17th century, paper became commonplace, and origami was able to be practiced by more people in Japan. Today, origami is a globalized pastime, especially because paper is sold in ready-made squares in many different colors to be instantly used and enjoyed.
